questions.question_text: You want to join the driving lane of the Highway from the accelerating lane but cannot join immediately due to high traffic density. Where must you stop, if necessary?

options.a: At the beginning of the accelerating lane to gain maximum speed later.
options.b: Toward the end of the accelerating lane.
options.c: On the hard shoulder to wait for the traffic to clear.

questions.explanation: According to the manual, if you cannot merge safely, you must continue to the end of the accelerating lane and stop there if necessary. You must not stop at the beginning as you need distance to match the speed of Highway traffic.

questions.question_text: What adversely affects road safety in this situation?

options.a: Water thrown up by vehicles in front.
options.b: The use of high-beam headlights by following traffic.
options.c: A sudden increase in the road's speed limit.

questions.explanation: On wet roads, 'wheel-spray' created by vehicles ahead severely impairs visibility. This is a primary risk that requires motorists to increase their following distance.

questions.question_text: Why does driving on this stretch of road require greater alertness on the part of the motorist?

options.a: Because the road is designated as a high-speed clearway.
options.b: Because the road surface is uneven and road grip varies.
options.c: Because you must pull over every 5 kilometres to check tyre pressure.

questions.explanation: The manual states that greater alertness is required when the road surface is uneven, as grip varies and the vehicle may become unstable if speed is not adjusted.

questions.question_text: You have missed the Highway exit. What is the only correct and safe action to take?

options.a: Stop on the hard shoulder and reverse back to the exit.
options.b: Make a U-turn at the next gap in the central reservation.
options.c: Drive on to the next exit.

questions.explanation: The manual is clear: Reversing and U-turns are strictly prohibited on Highways. The only safe and legal action is to proceed to the next available exit.

questions.question_text: On a road outside a built-up area with three lanes in each direction, which lane may you use for continuous travel if individual vehicles are travelling in the far-left lane?
questions.explanation: Outside built-up areas with three lanes, the middle lane may be used continuously if the left lane is occupied by slower-moving vehicles, even if they are well spaced out.

questions.question_text: What is the primary risk you must reckon with in this residential area?

options.a: Junctions may be ignored and children may run into the road unexpectedly.
options.b: The road is likely to be a high-speed clearway for motor vehicles.
options.c: Oncoming traffic will be legally required to move to the hard shoulder.

questions.explanation: Residential areas are high-risk zones where junctions are frequently overlooked and children often run into the roadway from between parked cars.

questions.question_text: Why must you maintain a particularly large safe distance from the vehicle in front when the road is wet?

options.a: Because your reaction time is naturally slower in the rain.
options.b: Because braking distances are greater than on a dry road.
options.c: Because it is required to allow the car behind to overtake you.

questions.explanation: Braking distance increases on wet roads because there is less friction between the tyres and the roadway. A larger distance ensures you have enough room to stop safely.

questions.question_text: A traffic jam has formed on a three-lane Highway. Where must the channel for emergency vehicles be formed?

options.a: Between the left-hand and the middle lanes.
options.b: Between the right-hand and the middle lanes.
options.c: Exclusively on the left-hand hard shoulder.

questions.explanation: On a three-lane Highway, the emergency channel (Rettungsgasse) must be created between the far-right lane and the middle lane.

questions.question_text: What must you reckon with when you see hazard warning lights flashing on a stationary vehicle?

options.a: A traffic jam, a broken-down vehicle, or a school bus with children alighting.
options.b: That the driver is signaling their intention to overtake you.
options.c: That the vehicle is about to accelerate rapidly.

questions.explanation: Hazard lights draw attention to dangers such as accidents, breakdowns, the end of a traffic jam, or a school bus where children are boarding or alighting.

questions.question_text: Using the rule of thumb, what is the BRAKING distance if you are travelling at 100 km/h?
questions.explanation: The formula for braking distance is (Speed/10) x (Speed/10). For 100 km/h, the calculation is 10 x 10 = 100 metres.

questions.question_text: What can result from driving for a long time at high speed on a good, wide road?

options.a: An increase in your concentration and field of vision.
options.b: A tendency to lose your feel for speed and underestimate it.
options.c: The engine becoming more efficient and reducing fuel consumption.

questions.explanation: Long-duration high-speed driving causes 'speed adaptation,' where the driver underestimates their actual speed, often leading to entering exits or bends too fast.

questions.question_text: You are approaching the vehicles in the picture. What must you do?

options.a: Stay in the middle lane, reduce speed and do not overtake the cars.
options.b: Switch to the right-hand lane and accelerate to pass the truck.
options.c: Use your horn and headlights to force the truck to move over.

questions.explanation: When approaching slower traffic on the Highway, the safest conduct is to remain in your lane, adjust your speed, and avoid dangerous overtaking maneuvers.

questions.question_text: What is the maximum speed at which you are allowed to drive a car towing a trailer on the Highway?
questions.explanation: The specific speed limit for a car with a trailer on the Highway is 80 km/h, regardless of the general speed limit of the road.

questions.question_text: What is the correct way to take a tight bend?

options.a: Maintain your speed and start braking halfway through the bend.
options.b: Reduce speed before reaching the bend and only accelerate again when the road straightens out.
options.c: Brake hard while turning to keep the vehicle from swinging out.

questions.explanation: Braking should be done in a straight line *before* the bend. Accelerating out of the bend only once the steering is straightened maintains vehicle stability.

questions.question_text: While driving, how can you safely check whether the road is slippery?

options.a: By steering sharply from side to side to feel the tyre grip.
options.b: By carefully applying the brakes at very low speed.
options.c: By accelerating rapidly to see if the traction control light flashes.

questions.explanation: The manual states that the safest way to test for slipperiness is to apply the brakes carefully at a very low speed when it is safe to do so.
